verse_text: Jesus answered, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God.'
title: John 3:5 — ‘born of water and Spirit’
summary: A key anchor text later traditions read in different ways: direct baptismal reference vs broader spiritual renewal.

verse_text: He saved us, not because of works done by us in righteousness, but according to his own mercy, by the washing of regeneration and renewal of the Holy Spirit.
title: Titus 3:5 — ‘washing of regeneration’
summary: Frequently cited as a direct link between salvation, washing, and renewal by the Holy Spirit.

verse_text: And Peter said to them, 'Repent and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.'
title: Acts 2:38 — baptism ‘for the forgiveness of sins’
summary: Connects repentance, baptism, forgiveness; debates focus on how baptism relates to the forgiveness it proclaims.

verse_text: Baptism, which corresponds to this, now saves you, not as a removal of dirt from the body but as an appeal to God for a good conscience, through the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
title: 1 Peter 3:21 — ‘Baptism… now saves you’
summary: Strong salvation language paired with clarification that it is not mere external washing; later debates hinge on that clarification.

title: Justin Martyr, First Apology ch. 61 — regeneration language
summary: Justin describes baptism in conversion as connected with being ‘regenerated’ in a context of repentance and belief.

title: Justin Martyr, First Apology ch. 66 — ‘washing… remission… regeneration’
summary: Justin links baptismal washing to remission of sins and regeneration in the life of the Church.

title: Cyprian, Epistle to Fidus — infant baptism and forgiveness
summary: Cyprian’s counsel on infant baptism assumes baptism is closely connected with forgiveness/remission logic.

title: Augustine — baptism of infants and remission of sins
summary: Augustine argues baptism grants remission of sins even to infants, tying the issue to original sin and salvation debates.

title: Aquinas, ST III q.69 — effects of baptism (‘laver of regeneration’)
summary: Aquinas systematizes baptism’s effects, citing Titus 3:5 and connecting baptism to regeneration and remission of sins.

title: Luther, Small Catechism — baptism gives forgiveness and salvation
summary: Luther teaches baptism ‘works forgiveness of sins’ and gives salvation, grounded in God’s promise and received in faith.

title: Luther, Large Catechism — Word + water; not ‘mere water’
summary: Luther rejects reducing baptism to a bare external; its power is the Word joined to water, and he uses ‘laver of regeneration’ language.

title: Westminster Confession ch. 28 — efficacy not tied to the moment
summary: Westminster affirms real conferral of grace by the Spirit but denies a mechanical tie to the moment of administration.

title: Zwingli — baptism as covenant sign (summary)
summary: Zwingli emphasizes baptism as covenant sign/marker rather than traditional regenerating instrumentality.

title: Thirty-Nine Articles, Article 27 — ‘sign of regeneration… as by an instrument’
summary: Anglican formularies describe baptism as more than a badge: a sign of regeneration/new birth ‘as by an instrument’ when rightly received.

title: Catechism of the Catholic Church — baptism as regeneration through water and the word
summary: The Catechism summarizes baptism as regeneration/new birth and liberation from sin, with incorporation into Christ and the Church.

verse_text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
title: John 1:1 — 'In the beginning was the Word'
summary: The prologue of John identifies the Logos (Word) with God and as the agent of creation, foundational for later Trinitarian formulations.

verse_text: I and the Father are one.
title: John 10:30 — 'I and the Father are one'
summary: Jesus claims unity with the Father, interpreted variously as functional unity or ontological oneness, central to Christological debates.

verse_text: Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit.
title: Matthew 28:19 — Baptism 'in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit'
summary: The Great Commission's triadic formula becomes a foundation for Trinitarian theology and liturgical practice.

title: Justin Martyr — Logos theology
summary: Justin describes the Son as the Logos who was with God from eternity and through whom God created, adapting philosophical categories for Christian theology.

title: Tertullian — First use of 'Trinity' (Trinitas)
summary: Tertullian coins the term 'Trinity' (Trinitas) and develops the formula 'one substance, three persons' against modalist heresies.

title: Arius and the Arian Controversy
summary: Arius teaches that the Son is a created being ('there was when he was not'), sparking the controversy that led to the Council of Nicaea.

title: Council of Nicaea (325) — Homoousios
summary: The first ecumenical council declares the Son 'homoousios' (of one substance) with the Father, condemning Arianism in the Nicene Creed.

title: Council of Constantinople (381) — Niceno-Constantinopolitan Creed
summary: Expands the Nicene Creed to affirm the full divinity of the Holy Spirit ('who proceeds from the Father') against Macedonianism.

title: Filioque clause added in the West
summary: The phrase 'and the Son' (Filioque) is gradually added to the Creed in the West, becoming a major point of division with the East.

title: Athanasian Creed — Trinitarian and Christological precision
summary: The Quicunque vult articulates the Trinity and Incarnation with detailed precision, widely used in Western liturgy.

verse_text: I am the living bread that came down from heaven. If anyone eats of this bread, he will live forever. And the bread that I will give for the life of the world is my flesh... For my flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink.
title: John 6:51-56 — 'My flesh is true food'
summary: Jesus declares that his flesh is real food and his blood real drink; those who eat and drink have eternal life. Foundational for Eucharistic theology.

verse_text: For I received from the Lord what I also delivered to you, that the Lord Jesus on the night when he was betrayed took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it, and said, 'This is my body, which is for you. Do this in remembrance of me.'
title: 1 Corinthians 11:23-29 — Institution and worthy reception
summary: Paul recounts the Last Supper tradition and warns against eating and drinking 'without discerning the body.'

title: Ignatius of Antioch — Eucharist as 'medicine of immortality'
summary: Ignatius describes the Eucharist as the flesh of Christ and 'medicine of immortality,' showing early belief in real presence.

title: Cyril of Jerusalem — Mystagogical Catecheses on the Eucharist
summary: Cyril teaches that after the invocation of the Spirit, the bread and wine become the body and blood of Christ.

title: Fourth Lateran Council (1215) — Transubstantiation defined
summary: The Council officially employs 'transubstantiation' to describe the change of bread and wine into Christ's body and blood.

title: Thomas Aquinas — Summa on the Eucharist
summary: Aquinas provides the definitive scholastic synthesis of Eucharistic theology, explaining transubstantiation using Aristotelian categories.

title: Luther — Real Presence 'in, with, and under'
summary: Luther rejects transubstantiation but affirms that Christ's body and blood are truly present in, with, and under the bread and wine (sacramental union).

title: Zwingli — The Lord's Supper as memorial
summary: Zwingli argues that 'This is my body' means 'signifies' — the Supper is a memorial and confession of faith, not a means of grace.

title: Marburg Colloquy (1529) — Luther and Zwingli disagree
summary: Luther and Zwingli fail to reach agreement on the Lord's Supper, dividing the Protestant Reformation on Eucharistic theology.

title: Calvin — Spiritual presence through the Holy Spirit
summary: Calvin mediates between Luther and Zwingli: Christ is truly present in the Supper, but spiritually — believers are lifted to heaven by the Spirit to commune with Christ.

title: Council of Trent — Reaffirms transubstantiation
summary: In response to Protestant challenges, Trent reaffirms transubstantiation and the sacrificial character of the Mass.
